posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Hi
I was inspired by an exchange of ideas in a recent thread and wanted to see what it is like to play a character with extremely low HP.
I decided to play a sorcerer with its d4 die.  As for module , I chose the OC (plague campaign).  It is not too difficult and can serve as a well-known reference module.

To make it interesting I made the following rules:
  • No henchmen
  • No summons to hide behind in combat
  • No familiar in combat
  • Can use familiar out of combat for scouting, rogue skills etc.
  • No constitution enhancing items are allowed.
  • Can use spells and potions to enhance constitution.
  • Hardcore DnD difficulty mode
  • Permadeath – no reloading, no respawning.
The build:
Elven sorceress
Str 12, Dex 16, Con 6, Int 12, Wis 8, Cha 18
Skills: Concentration, Spellcraft and Search (x-classed)
Planned pre-epic feats: SF Evocation, Extend spell, Silent spell, Empower spell, SF Necromancy, GSF Necromancy, Maximize spell.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Spoiler alert!!!!
If you are new to this game and/or have not played the official campaign yet, beware!

The Academy
First I went to the merchant. He gave my charactert a robe of fire resistance that I decided to keep for later. Then I grabbed every item in the containers and sold to the store for a good price, except a heavy x-bow and some leftover scrolls that I wanted to keep.  I did the caster quest and quick-slotted the frost wand.
I went to see Beth for what should have been the initiation ceremony. Afterwards I buffed up with the Mage armor and Shield spells for a temporary AC of 20 before returning to face the goblin invasion.
It is rather scary to face even the weak goblins when playing a character with no armor and only 2 HP. Even if they only can hit you on a very high roll, when they hit, they deal 1 HP damage, 50% of your total HP pool. Get hit twice and you are dead.
I tried to keep distance and avoid damage. The weak goblins were slow moving one-hit kills. The weak skeletons were faster, but also they were easy to put to rest.
Just before I met up with the NPC that let you level up for the first time, there was a Tough Goblin, faster than the previous ones, with more HP and a heavier attack.
He landed a devastating 3 HP hit – and that was the end of the permadeath challenge!

 
I decided to keep playing, but after having died already I had to drop the permadeath rule. So I reloaded and this time I was able to run and gun and survive to reach the first level up.
I felt a bit more confident now with 4 HP. It all went well until I had to face the mage in the large hall, just before the end of the prelude. He cast frost rays. They damage 2-5 HP, meaning with 4 HP there is a 50% death risk from one hit, so my character bit the dust once more. I regretted badly that I had not picked the Endure elements spell on the level up. However, I had a wand with two fireball spells that had dropped from the aforementioned tough goblin. I was able to direct the fireballs near the mage, without being detected. The two fireballs ended the fight.
After reaching level 3 I almost felt invincible with 6 HP.

Beggar's nest
I now entered the city and decided to start with the Beggar's nest. Normally I start with the Peninsula, but in this case it was too tempting to level up my character by clearing the streets of slow moving zombies, using a ranged weapon and the wand of frost.
With level 4 I got the first lvl 2 spell. I chose Ghostly visage for the 5/+1 DR effect. Later I was able to buy a robe with DR 5/+1 and then picked Endurance and Melf’s acid arrow on the next level up.
As for level 1 spells I took MA, Shield, Endure elements, Magic missile and Protection from alignment. I think it was in that order.
I cleared the entire Beggars nest except the final boss fight with Gulnan and reached level 6 with a whopping 12 HP and my first level 3 spell – Fireball.
My character died twice in the process. One death was from being careless and stepping on a floor trap. The second was a one hit kill when fighting the spider before entering the graveyard.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Peninsula
The Peninsula was not so hard after first leveling up in the Beggars nest.
It was a joy to fireball the escaped prisoners. But beware that on Hardcore DnD difficulty fireballs can be suicidal, especially with the low HP. You soon get a feel for where to direct the spell so you don’t hit yourself. The safest is to aim at a fixed spot on the floor. It is easier to hit a group of moving targets if you aim the spell at a character in the middle of the group. But that can be a little hazardous if they are running towards you. If you cast too late, you risk being hit by our own spell. Casting an elemental resistance spell on yourself or wearing fire resist robes cuts you a little  slack.
The fight against the sorcerer on level 2 in the prison was interesting. We were at about the same level and used much the same spells against each other. Wearing fire protection helped a lot, but I suffered one death.
The different gang leaders and the boss on level 3 in the prison, were too hard to face toe to toe, so I practiced some run’n gun/Fireball/Melf’s/MM tactics. To wear them down this way can be a bit tedious, especially when they start quaffing healing potions. With a little patience, they run out of potions and fall in the end.
After convincing the enthralled prison guards to leave and then putting some arrows in their chief, I could stand and cast spells at the devourer until it succumbed.

Afterwards I returned to the Beggars nest for the boss fight with Gulnan. On the first attempt, my character was killed by a negative energy spell. I reloaded and enjoyed a prolonged battle against a boss that was able to resist some of my spells and could heal herself with both spells and potions.

With level 7 I had also taken Lightning bolt and Lesser dispel. Lightning bolt is very good for close combat because you do not risk burning yourself like with the fireball. It is also great for zapping foes chasing you in a line. Mestil’s acid breath is an alternative spell here for close combat, but I chose the Lightning bolt for its slightly longer reach. Lesser dispel was useful against mages and other buffed creatures that now started to appear from time to time.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Blacklake

The first part of Blacklake was quite easy now, fighting diseased mobs and rabid dogs. The half-orc bully that ruled the neighborhood was much tougher. His axe was far too dangerous for close combat, threatening one hit kills even if I buffed my sorcerer with Endurance for potentially 28 HP. So I pulled him out of his house and ran down the streets casting all manners of spells in his direction until he fell.
I hit level 8 while doing the Never’s Tomb quest in Blacklake. The floating swords are dangerous, but it helps to keep the distance and they take full damage from magic.

Stoneskin was my first level 4 spell. Armed with my new protection I went to the tavern to join the fight arena. All my adversaries there were spell resistant, this was obviously not a quest for mages. There was absolutely no use in attack spells. They cast Dispel on you when you enter the ring, so you cannot buff up before battle. Well, there I was with my now 16 HP, wearing robes and facing seasoned gladiators, some of them flanked by large cats and wolves. I wore the DR robe and casted Stoneskin on entering the ring. That bought me time to get up the rest of my defensive spells. I also had a brawler belt I could use against the unarmed fighter.
I wanted to keep the distance and used the bow to harm most of them. The unarmed fighter was only vulnerable to blunt weapons. I had a club that was able to hit him, but I could also have used a sling. In hindsight, I wonder if a reciprocal damage shield, the death armor, could have helped. I could even have extended it for a 16 rounds duration.
The last combatant played foul and entered the ring fully buffed. I was able to handle that with Lesser dispel. Finally, and against the odds, I had defeated all my adversaries and won the tavern.

I entered two estates to get the quest items for Ophala. I let my Pixie take care of traps and locks. Combat against the guards turned out to be quite easy. I simply let my familiar hang back while frying them with different kinds of spells.
The Zoo was about the same difficulty as the two estates, only there were two lesser bosses that it took a few more spells to defeat.
At this point my 16 HP character started to feel powerful the way you would expect with any other lvl 8 sorcerer.

Entering the Meldanen estate changed that feeling.  Here was a mixture of locks and traps, regular guards, watch dogs, magical creatures and spell casters of varying difficulty. Suffering a two hit kill from a Stag beetle reminded me to be more cautious.
The boss himself went down on my second attempt. On the first try he fired some kind of mind- or hold spell and won easily. On my second attempt I leaped out of sight and won the fight by spamming fireballs on him so he failed all his concentration checks.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
The Docks

Clearing the streets of Muggers, Thugs and different ruffians was not so hard now at level 8. Soon level 9 was reached.
I chose ILMS for my next level 4 spell. Other candidates would be Improved invisibility, Ice storm and Elemental shield. I chose ILMS for now because I wanted a non-save non-elemental single target attack spell that was better than MM and I already had several area of attack spells. I also upgraded from the level 1 spell Endure elements to its level 3 counterpart Protection from elements. I took Expeditious retreat in the free level 1 slot to improve the run speed for 18 rounds when extended. I could have taken Haste instead, but wanted to save my level 3 and 4 casting for other spells at this stage. I could always drink a Haste potion if I needed a higher casting rate.
At this level up, I also took the Empower spell feat.  I started to buff with empowered Endurance for a larger HP pool and empowered Eagles for a better spells DC. With a lucky roll (50%), I could now reach 45 HP with empowered Endurance, which is getting close to the base HP of a normal sorcerer build. There is still the danger of being dispelled or trying to rest with low HP, taking your HP below 0 and killing you when the spell runs out.
Most of the Bloodsailors were easy. Some of their officers took a little longer to defeat. In the Silver Sails trading company building there were several vermin, some of them rather tough. All in all the Docks, including the side quests and the Callik fight was not very challenging now. 

Helm’s hold

I entered the hold through the cave and cleared the cellar/dungeon of zombies. The false Helmites fell easily. I used speed tactics in the large hall and library before the stairs up, to herd the undead foes together to use AOE spells on them.
The undead in the courtyard turned out to be a rather difficult fight. There spawned two Bodaks among the other undead. With no death protection items and no death protection spells, it was best to stay away from their death gaze. The best solution was to split them apart by pulling them one by one out the gate, and attacking from distance. My sorcerer died twice before I was able to get it right.
After clearing all areas, I released the guardian armors and killed them one by one for the extra xp.
At the altar, I chose the good solution and pocketed a ring of elemental protection.
 
Desther

This was a tough fight for two reasons. The first is the sheer number of undead you have to fight before you get to the boss, and the second is that Desther will dispel you and cast slay living among other attack spells.
There is no place to rest and you cannot return downstairs once you are up on the top floor.
You have to save your spells.  Scrolls and wands help.
I was able to handle most of the undead by first taking care of the small rooms one by one. I even survived another Bodak.
When I opened the door to the main hall, I created a choke point in the door opening and cast a couple of fireballs on the amassed undead. I had enough elemental protection and HP to survive that.
The ritual creatures were resistant to spells, so I picked them from a distance with the bow. I was able to do that without being detected by edging along the walls near the door.
The one on one fight with Desther was a disaster until I discovered a fatal weakness on his part; he can not have any concentration skill to speak of. When I was out of attack spells, I was still able to stall him by firing from a bow and from a MM wand. I used the extended Expeditious retreat to stay ahead of him.
He has very high HP, but he surrendered while still only being barely damaged.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
With increasing levels I feel that the 2HP challenge becomes less and less of a challenge (trying not to get too cocky here). Of course it is still a handicap, but there are more and more ways to get around it. Damage reduction and damage resistance from spells (and items) help a lot. Being able to buff with empowered constitution also gives a temporary HP pool. Polymorph, tensers and scapechange will offer forms with increased HP if there is no way around soaking up damage.
Another point is that the easy way to survive low levels with an arcane caster is to use summons as meat shields. It was part of this challenge not to do that, and I have now reached a level where I normally would go without summons in combat unless there are rest restrictions. That means that I have passed that part of the challenge.

I wonder if there is any point in going on with this now since it becomes more and more like playing a normal sorcerer.
Of course there is the adventure and sometimes it is good to read what others do and how they handle things.

Taking the adventure to Aielund, but with 1 HP this time (thank you Web for the idea), with a slightly different magic system (EMS hak) and trying to survive act 1 (ending at level 10) is tempting at this stage.

What do you think?

posts.author: The Flying Rodent
posts.content:
Well, it's been a while. I had to create a new account to reply to this because the internets swallowed my old one. But we made it, so yay!

For context on who I am, I'm this guy ...

bearded-battlemage-oc-wizard-15-fighter ... 54619.html

... and seeing a post about completing the OC with a funky spellcaster piqued my interest.

I may not go through with this personally, but if someone perhaps wants to: there is a very nice tactic that arcane spellcaster can use for the Prelude in the first Chapter. To quote myself:

One can run through the entire Prelude, picking up the 2 levels from the conversations, and then backtrack through killing all the monsters picking up ANOTHER level. This will get your character to level 4 by the beginning of Chapter 1, and makes things a lot easier!

The trick is to run through under the cover of Faerie Dragon invisibility. After fighting the initial wave and talking with Aribeth, summon your familiar and rest. This will give you a familiar summon charge for later on. Possess your Faerie Dragon, then left, top left, right on the radial menu to access Improved Invisibility and cast it on the player. Given you're level 1 wizard, it'll only last a minute, so you'll have to be quick. Unsummon your dragon after invising yourself, and run to Gerand. If you're lucky, you can find him and shut the door behind you 'just' before it wears off.

With enemies nearby, you won't be able to rest here. Level up to level 2 [but take wizard this time], summon your familiar again, and repeat! Smash all the goblins in front of Fenthick/Desther, and take a 3rd Wizard level. Take Ghostly Visage and Flame Weapon. Backtrack through the Prelude and smash/frost rod everything.

Perhaps someone undertaking the challenge can adopt this tactic and use it to get an easy level 4.

Been a fun read. Looks like a good challenge, might have to try it myself at some point when I'm not swamped with work lol.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I finally took the build to Aielund and played through act 1. I rerolled for 1 HP per level (except for level 1-3) and ended up with lvl 10 and 13 HP.
In many ways Aielund is harder than the OC and especially the early challenges when everything is low magic and your character is weak. 
But some things worked in my favour. With EMS the spell Mage armor gives a +4 armor AC bonus and the spell Shield gives a +4 shield AC bonus making it much easier for a mage to buff up a fair amount of AC. And that was especially important with a fragile build like this one.
Once I was able to collect about 5K gold (and it takes some time), I could buy a pair of boots  that grants permanent +50% speed, just like a permanent expeditious retreat spell, so i could run and gun (or cast spells).
There is also an item that let you cast lvl5 Magic missile unlimited, saving you a lot of resting, but you cannot afford to buy it right  from the start. Once you get it, it helps you through several levels until you need (and get) spells with more oomph. All in all those items made early levelling much easier.
